subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Shavian and Quikscript: legibility
msgSnippet: ... It sure sounds that way. ... You ve got R and L reversed sometimes, as you probably know by now. Then the bowsprit got mixed with the rudder sometimes: A
messageBody:
Nathan Sharfi scripsit:

> [At this point the blackletter analogy is looking strained, and a
> better one would be "an English speaker trying to read English text
> transliterated into Greek…and all the Greek they know they learned
> in college physics and chemistry classes."]

It sure sounds that way.

> ["I collected this site to ?lektis writing and reading in v Shaw script."]

You've got R and L reversed sometimes, as you probably know by now.

Then the bowsprit got mixed with the rudder sometimes:
A thing, as the Bellman remarked,
That frequently happens in tropical climes,
When a vessel is, so to speak, "snarked".

> This isn't like reading things set in Lucida Blackletter — it's like
> reading something written by someone who hasn't noticed that their
> normally QWERTY keyboard layout is set to Colemak.

A rgpueukd umadf, cfpgaukij, blg ag ifarg uk Cyifmae aii ghf ifggfpr
apf rguii Iaguk, kyg a muxglpf yt ghf tamuiuap aks ghf rgpakdf.

Which is just "A striking image, certainly, but at least in Colemak
all the letters are still Latin, not a mixture of the familiar and
the strange." typed on a Colemak keyboard. Much less legible than the
Shavian, if much more Lovecraftian than the QWERTY.

> Of course, I wouldn't be *too* surprised if someone weird enough to
> be interested in either Shavian or QS were able to recite the opening
> paragraph of anything Lovecraft verbatim with only minimal prompting,

Indeed. See <http://www.gamegrene.com/wiki/Exingians>.

--
Why are well-meaning Westerners so concerned that John Cowan
the opening of a Colonel Sanders in Beijing means cowan@...
the end of Chinese culture? [...] We have had http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
Chinese restaurants in America for over a century,
and it hasn't made us Chinese. On the contrary,
we obliged the Chinese to invent chop suey. --Marshall Sahlins
